awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Liquid Metal Tuned Flexible Metasurfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:

Optical windows such as lenses in prescription glasses are reasonably customizable. Lenses can vary in size, shape, curvature, or design. In addition to aesthetic features, the functionalities and overall packaging can also be modified or upgraded. For example, anti-reflective coatings can be added to reduce glare and photochromic lenses suppress light transmission on exposure to ultraviolet radiation. These optional features have minimal impact on physical properties since such coatings add less than a millimeter of thickness. Microwave windows can be considered as a type of optical window that functions in the microwave spectrum. As with optical windows, microwave windows are made to transmit, reflect, or absorb electromagnetic waves. Microwave windows are indispensable components in systems such as radomes (enclosures that protect a radar antennas) and shields that reduce electromagnetic interference. Unlike optical windows, current design techniques do not lend much freedom to customize both functional and physical characteristics of the microwave windows.  For example, practical microwave windows that are flexible, thickness customizable, and can tune the transfer response on-demand in real-time remain to be realized. This project will exploit new techniques that can be applied to realize liquid metal enabled tunable and mechanically flexible multi-layered microwave windows. The proposed device will be made by integrating movable liquid metals that can provide a wide tuning range with minimal loss. The resulting concept can be adapted to all types of filters, delivering unprecedented design control in the implementation of multi-layered tunable/flexible microwave windows. The educational and outreach plan focuses on students from underrepresented groups, integrating research findings into classroom courses taught by the PIs and developing active collaboration with industry.

Technical:

The objectives of this proposal are to study new theoretical foundations and explore the potentials and limitations of liquid metal tuned mechanically flexible (bendable/foldable) metasurfaces.  The technical approach relies on adopting a multi-layer metasurface synthesis technique based on thickness customizable intercoupling layers that behave as admittance inverters. The proposed liquid metal tuned mechanically flexible metasurfaces consist of gallium-based liquid metal slugs in polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) microfluidic channels as moveable tuning elements and another gallium alloy filled in specific metasurface pattern as fixed metal. These liquid metal slugs will be made oxide free and freely movable in the microfluidic channel. Thus, the position of the moveable liquid metal slug train in a large 2D array metasurface can be tuned pneumatically with high precision. The reconfigurable property makes microwave windows attractive for a wide range of applications that demand controllable/stable high-frequency response when operated under a dynamic EM environment. When combined with the flexibility feature, the new technology can revolutionize the use of next-generation microwave windows by enabling deployable, transportable, and conformable metasurfaces that can be tuned on-demand, in real-time. The end result is a significant scientific leap in metasurface technology and establishment of the principles and the feasibility of new technologies for future metasurface-based devices and systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

NSF Award Number ECCS-1908546

Collaborative Research: Liquid Metal Tuned Flexible Metasurfaces

Project/Grant Period: 9/1/2019 - 8/31/2023

 

This project aimed to discover and apply new techniques for realizing multilayered metasurfaces that are mechanically flexible and tunable in real-time using liquid metal. The project has led to significant advancements in metasurface technology for transmission, reflection, or absorption of electromagnetic waves. The developed design techniques enable customizable metasurfaces that can adapt, in electromagnetic response and/or in physical shape, to changing environments or functions.

 

Transmitting surfaces: Under this project, novel frequency selective surfaces (FSSs) were developed using liquid metal embedded in polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS). These surfaces prevent undesired energy from passing through, while allowing transmission of desired signals. The material properties of liquid metal and PDMS provide the additional advantages of tunable and/or reconfigurable filter responses with mechanical flexibility. A flexible multilayer FSS with a tunable second-order bandpass response was designed using a combination of fixed and pneumatically moveable liquid metal in PDMS channels. Following this work, a synthesis technique for designing thickness customizable higher order (N ≥ 2) bandpass FSSs was adapted to use with our liquid-metal-tuned metasurface technology. Bandpass and bandstop prototype surfaces were fabricated by collaborators from the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD), and their filtering responses were verified in waveguide and free space environments at the University at Buffalo Microwave lab (https://www.eng.buffalo.edu/~junhchoi/). The flexible surfaces were found to also exhibit self-healing properties that allowed easy repair even after making cuts through the devices.      

 

Reflecting surfaces: This project produced a variety of new reflecting type surface designs. For the first time, a liquid-metal-tuned reflecting element for reflectarrays or reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) was introduced. The flexible element provides over 360° of tunable reflection phase, and is suitable for realizing deployable or conformal reflecting surfaces that are reconfigurable (direction, shape, or number of beams) in real-time. This project also introduced a new design method, based on composite right/left-handed (CRLH) transmission lines, for realizing frequency scanning reflecting metasurfaces. These metasurfaces allow for low-cost beam steering controlled completely by the transmitter frequency, which can be beneficial for both reflectarrays and RISs. This project also explored techniques to improve the tracking capability of chipless RFIDs by implementing a retrodirective surface.

 

Absorbing surfaces: New developments in metasurface absorbers took place under this project. These metal-backed devices prevent reflections within a certain frequency range by absorbing the incoming electromagnetic energy. For the first time, a liquid-metal-tuned absorber with a continuously tunable absorption band was introduced. The flexible metasurface is less than 1.5 mm thick, which allows for easy transportation and mounting to arbitrary surfaces. The project also led to progress in high power microwave absorbers with plasma-based tuning. A multilayer tunable metasurface absorber was designed and its maximum power handling was evaluated using multiphysics (electromagnetic coupled with thermal) simulation, with experimental validation.
